conversations.content: Dear Bro, Dear Sis, Thanks for the letter! Glad you're doing well. My chef training at the Halidom is continuing pretty much like always, I guess.
I know it's tough to keep the restaurant running, and I'm sorry. It's mostly my fault, after all, seeing as how I wasn't able to live up to the expectations Dad had for me.
I want to become a chef even greater than him— No, I HAVE to. So I'm going to keep working at it day and night. Until then, good luck! —Mitsuba
*sigh* Guess that's good enough.
Um...'scuse me?
Gah! Noelle?! How long have you been here?!
Um, a few minutes? Sorry! I knocked and you answered, so I...came in.
...You did? Huh. Honestly, I was so absorbed in my letter that I must have responded without even realizing it.
Anyway, whatcha need?
Um, r-right. Well, I'm heading up north tomorrow, so if you have any letters or things to send, I can, um...collect them?
The work of a messenger really never ends, huh? But yeah, I've got something  for you if it's not too much trouble.
Besides, my letters have been arriving faster lately if I send them through North Grastaea.
I think that's how it is this time of year. Trade with neighboring countries gets more active before all the...um...snow.
Still, it sounds like you want it delivered fast. Is something the matter?
Oh, just the family business not doing so hot again. Same old, same old.
They could really use me in the kitchen, but I'm all the way over here training to become a better chef. It's...hard.
Your family business is, um... a restaurant, right?
That's right, a place called Nanakusa. One of the fanciest joints in all of Hinomoto.
My sister helps out, but she runs another restaurant and can only do so much. Honestly, we're in deep trouble if we can't restore the reputation my father had.
And I'm the second-generation head chef, so it's up to me to make that happen.
Don't be so hard on yourself, Mitsuba!
I try not to, but...yeah.
I mean, there isn't much of a choice here. If I want to surpass Dad and give his customers the experience they want, I have to carve my own path as a chef.
So that means practice and work day and night without pause!
Oh dear...
*yawn* ...Hmm? What's all this food doing here so early in the morning?
Mornin', Cleo!
Hello, Mitsuba. I assume I have you to thank for this veritable mountain of food?
Yeah, there were a few dishes I wanted to try out, so I made breakfast.
This is less ＂a few dishes＂ and more of a banquet. Were you cooking all night long?
Yep. Couldn't help myself.
So what Noelle told me was true.
Noelle? What'd she say?
She came to me before she set out and told me how you are tormenting yourself about your family restaurant. She then asked for me to check in on you.
I understand your situation, but you'll not get anywhere if you put such pressure on yourself without end.
But I—
No buts. Let me instead ask you this: What did you achieve from staying up all night cooking?
Well, um...I'm tired?
You'll do your family no good if you end up working yourself to death.
In fact, the time I most recently saw your cooking shine is when we were roasting fiends outdoors with Pecorine.
Surely it would be better training to cook in a relaxed fashion such as that?
Come to think of it, you're right... I was really in the zone back there.
It made me feel like my cooking was... I dunno. Worthwhile, I guess?
Agreed. Pecorine may have savored eating the food, but making it was also fun in its own right.
Camping and cooking... Hmm...
Are you all right, Mitsuba? I lost you there for a moment.
Actually, if you don't mind...
Would you head into the mountains with me so we can cook outdoors?
The mountains? Again?
Well, it's doesn't have to be mountains, specifically. Anywhere outside is fine.
If I can just experience the sense of worth I did while I was camping, I think it might really do me some good.
I can learn something I won't be able to if I'm shut up in a kitchen—and maybe even something that will finally let me surpass Dad.
Er, we seem to be discussing two things rather far removed from each other...
(I feel like she raced right by my point about letting the training go for a bit.)
(But perhaps this is just the change of pace that Mitsuba needs.)
Very well. I will accompany you. In truth, I rather enjoyed our outdoor cooking adventure and would like to do it again.
Oh, thanks! I'm gonna go get ready!
(As ever, she is earnest and dedicated to her craft—perhaps TOO much so.)
(But can she really find what she needs for a restaurant in the great outdo—)
Sorry to keep you waiting!
Those are the camping clothes you wore last time, yes? Goodness, but you got changed quickly.
When I decide to do something, I DO it! No point lollygagging around, right?
Anyway, we gotta shake the lead out, so go get changed! Go go gooooo!
Stop pushing me! I am going!
Whoa... So this is a rokkan village.
I heard this place and its ironwork is every bit the equal of Hinomotoan swordsmiths, and now I see why folks say that.
Pardon me, Mitsuba, but why exactly have we switched into these clothes and come to inspect a random rokkan outpost?
We're here to purchase what we're gonna need to master the art of outdoor cooking.
According to what Lazry said, it should be riiiight arooooound... Ah, there it is! This is our stop.
A cookware shop?
That's right! She says it's a specialty place that only sells cookware made with rokkan smithing techniques.
Rokkan iron is famous for its sturdiness, which should make it perfect for camping.
So we've come to buy the best cookware for outdoor work, eh?
I'm very particular about my gear. If you're going to cook, you can't cut a single corner.
Corner-cutting is an insult to both the food and the people who eat it!
*sigh* Spoken like a true restaurateur.
Very well. However, let us be certain not to break our budget, yes?
Are you kidding? I come from a struggling restaurant! I am the MASTER of thrift! My belt is tighter than Ranzal's pants after he visits a buffet!
It's very reassuring to hear...most of that. Now as the Halidom's bulwark against  reckless spending, let us put our miserly heads together and shop wisely!
Whoaaa...
Look, Mitsuba! Apparently you can put this iron plate right on the fire and then eat straight off it without burning yourself!
Ahhh! And this super tiny tool lets you smoke an entire haunch of meat!
This shop is like a veritable treasure trove of handy tools and utensils.
Right? Er, and since they'd ALSO be super handy to have around the Halidom, we should probably buy 'em all, right?
Hmm. In principle, I do not enjoy spending lavishly like this, but...
Oh, believe me, I'm the same way. But since we'll use this forever, it's basically a long-term investment! ...Right?
Let's go SHOPPING!
Very good, ladies. Here is your total.
WHAT!
I didn't even know you could put that many zeros at the end of something...
It appears we have underestimated the price of rokkan ironware rather severely.
I fear we won't be able to afford more than a single piece.
Well then, let's decide which one it'll be.
Whatever we buy will be linked to our cooking lives for years to come. We must choose carefully.
Okay. Then on the count of three, we'll each yell out what we want.
A fine plan. Ready? One...two...THREE!
Roasting skewers!
Cooking shears!
WHAT?!
Skewers? That's absurd! If you wish to roast something, you can simply place it on some wire mesh and hang it over an open fire!
Ex-CUSE me?! Are you really standing there throwing shade on ROASTING?!
You just want scissors! SCISSORS, CLEO! Hell, Notte probably has an old pair of those just lying around! How will that possibly change your cooking experience?!
Oh, how naive you are, Mitsuba... For these are no ordinary shears!
In addition to being, as you say, ＂scissors,＂ they can also be separated and used as a pair of prep knives—one for meat and one for vegetables!
Cooking utensils live and die by their convenience, and we must make the most practical choice!
Are you nuts?! Cooking needs specificity! If you're going to spend money, do it on tools that let you make your dishes the right way—the ONLY way.
You're so WRONG!
Excuse me, ladies, but your frantic wailing is beginning to disturb the other guests. Might you kindly take this outside?
Rrrgh! You are SO stubborn!
And you're just a...a MULE! But still, the—
Stop. I know what you are going to say. The passion you have for cooking...
...IS WONDERFUL!
Heh.
Hee hee!
Aaah ha ha ha!
*sigh* This argument is very silly.
Cooking makes fools of us all. Oh, but more importantly, Cleo, I think I have a suggestion...
If we're only buying one thing... I think we should go with this.
A pot? ...Mmm, yes, that is rather nice. It's made with a rare iron-casting method, and is durable, lightweight, and quick to conduct heat.
AND the lid is made with high-quality iron, which means you can use it to steam stuff over a charcoal fire.
I imagine we could even use the lid as a skillet if we were to simply flip it over.
Right? With this one tool, we can roast, steam, and stew all in one.
It lets us do things the right way AND it is convenient—which makes it the item we both desire most.
Then let's get it already!
We will make so many delicious meals in you, Mr. Pot!
A few days later...
I think that's all of my bags. Mitsuba. Are you done getting ready?
Sure am. Let's set out!
(I'm going to find what I need to surpass Dad this time... I swear I am!)
Ahhh, there's the sweet mountain air I've been missing!
*wheeze* *paaant*
Er, you okay back there, Cleo? Should we take another break?
No, I'm fine... If we keep to my pace, the sun will set before we're able to do any proper cooking.
Now let's do this thing! *wheeze*
(Cleo's not much for mountain climbing, is she?)
(And yet, she's still come on this selfish little quest to improve my cooking skills.)
...Cleo, wait! I'll carry your bags!
That'll be quite unnecessary. You have plenty enough to lug around on your own.
Aw, it's no big thing!
Look, we've come all this way, right? Let's at least try to have some fun on the last stretch up the mountain.
That's very kind, Mitsuba, thank you. I think I shall take you up on it.
Leave 'er to me!
And...there. The tent is up.
We picked a pretty great spot here— there's a natural windbreak to keep us warm, and plenty of sunlight as well.
Now that we have our campsite, we should start foraging for ingredients.
I hear one can find a good number of trout in the nearby rivers.
Alberia has trout? I had no idea... Welp, let's get some hooks baited!
...Woof. Not even a nibble.
These river fish are cautious ones, aren't they? I think they may have noticed us and hid themselves away.
If that's the case, we could drop our lines all night long and still come up empty.
Which MEANS...
Er, Mitsuba? What are you doing with that very large knife?
I am a chef, and this knife is my weapon. Hundreds and thousands of fish have bent to my will before it.
And now I will use it to make the trout that lurk in this river yield as well!
Whether in the mountains or a kitchen, whether atop a cutting board or in the cool shadow of a mighty boulder, the grit of a chef is undying! HAHHH!
You caught a hidden trout with your KNIFE?!
I told you my knife skills are unmatched!
That was more akin to a bear catching salmon...
Anyway, now that we've got this fish, let's pick some edible plants on the way back and get to cooking!
Geez, there are so many pla... Hmm?
Oh my gosh, are those alpine leeks?! There's so MANY of them!
Are you referring to the ramsons there?
Ramsons, eh? Huh, you're right. They LOOK like alpine leeks, but they're actually something different entirely.
*sniff* Wow, they even SMELL the same. Actually, this could be a great discovery! Alpine leeks are super rare, but these could make the perfect substitution.
I could use them in salads, tempura, stir-fry... Heck, in practically everything! And this place is just chock FULL of 'em!
GIMME ALL YA GOT, PLANT! *pick* *pick* *pick* *pick* *pick*
*sigh* I don't know if it's quite THAT exciting, but she certainly seems happy in her own little world there.
...Mitsuba? The sun is setting. I know you are in a mad daze at the moment, but do try to retain a bit of control.
But I NEED this stuff, Cleo! I'm seriously gonna start using it in everything I cook from now on!
Yes yes, it truly is a miracle. Now let's return to camp and cook.
But...my ingredients!
The sun's all the way down now, so let's hurry and get to cooking.
Time to bust out the pot we bought back in the rokkan village.
This outdoor cooking trip is absolutely going to give me the inspiration I need to redefine my cooking!
So our ingredients for dinner are the plants we foraged from the woods, as well as the trout you so impressively caught.
I also have some Hinomotoan rice that I brought with me from the castle, as well as a few spices.
We went to the trouble of buying this pot, so how about we cook the rice with all of the other ingredients?
Cooking a variety of ingredients with rice is a Hinomotoan staple, is it not?
Sure is! It lets the flavors meld perfectly.
I'd actually been hoping to learn some Hinomotoan cooking for myself.
Then let's get the prep going!
Add the rice... Add the ingredients... Add the spice... We're ready, Mitsuba.
Now we just have to put it on the flame.
I hope it comes out delicious.
Me too. I'll keep an eye on the heat.
Thank you. I've heard it's quite difficult to properly cook Hinomotoan rice, after all.
Luckily, that sort of thing is my forte. You can just take five here, Cleo.
Okay, we should be ready. Let's open 'er up.
I can scarce contain my excitement!
Let's see...
The outside is completely burned, but the center is sort of...gooey?
Well, that is unfortunate. Wind direction and weather are hard to gauge in the mountains, so I imagine they affected the heat of the flame.
I'm sorry, Cleo.
And after I went on about how good I am at managing the heat, too...
You've done nothing wrong, Mitsuba. In fact, I was careless myself.
But I wasted all of our ingredients... AND your precious time!
I made you climb a MOUNTAIN for heck's sake, and now all you get is a gooey burnt mess for dinner.
Mitsuba...
Can't believe I thought I'd find the secret to being a better chef out here...
I'm just...sorry. About everything.
You're wrong, Mitsuba.
Huh?
I don't think today was a waste at all.
True, climbing the mountain was not my favorite part, but the rest of the time we spent together was delightful.
We may have failed with the food, but we still managed to make some truly wonderful memories together.
...You really think so?
I do—and I ALSO think failure makes for a stronger memory than a success.
Making a fine memory of your failure is what outdoor cooking is all about!
Hmm...
You know, I've never thought about it that way before.
That's because you always made food for your customers, not just for yourself.
Yeah, Dad was pretty unforgiving with mistakes—he yelled at me a lot.
But that's not what scared me away from slipping up.
Once I took over the restaurant, I knew any mistake I made would bring shame to the business. The more I thought about that, the less I tolerated my own failures.
...Heh. The smell of this burned rice is actually taking me back.
One time after I burnt a batch, Dad gave me this long lecture about how hard the farmers who grew the rice had worked... so we ended up eating it together anyway.
Heh, so even something as modest as burnt rice brings back fond memories of your father. How sweet.
And as such, shall we eat this together? This rice was born of a failure that came after we overcame many hardships—which makes it quite meaningful, if you ask me.
Heck yeah!
Here you are, Mitsuba! One heaping helping of rice with extra burned parts!
*chomp* *squish* Ha ha ha ha! Gosh, the middle of it really is like trying to chew a sponge.
Ha ha ha ha ha! It's terrible, Cleo! I mean, it is REALLY bad! Ha ha ha!
Hee hee! *munch* ...Actually, the burned rice doesn't taste half bad.
*munch* Hey, you're right. It's NOT bad. I mean...relatively. Ha ha ha ha ha!
Okay, this is DEFINITELY the hardest I've ever laughed in my life while eating rice.
Yet another of the pleasures gained from outdoor cooking.
Now let us eat until our bellies are round!
Oh, I'm on it. More, please!
So c-c-cold...
If you cling that closely to me, I won't be able to start a fire...
You say that, but you're not exactly making an effort to get away from me...
That is because I have nothing else to keep me warm.
But we're not going to get anywhere if we stay clung together like this.
Right then. Let us count to three, then both pull away at the same time.
Got it. One...two...THREE!
Nooooo!
Urgh.
Yep.
IT'S FREEZING!
*sigh* We finally got a fire started...
These mountain mornings sure are cold, aren't they?
Yeah. We should make sure to eat something toasty and warm for breakfast.
A fine plan—but what are we to make? All we have is some of the leftover rice we cooked up yesterday.
Are there any Hinomotoan recipes we could use to turn it into something nice?
Actually, I think I have just the thing.
If we boil some water and make a stock from yesterday's leftover plants...
Yes! We can make dashi chazuke! Lemme just do a liiiittle...
So you add dashi broth to the leftover rice, let it soak, and then eat it?
This looks warm and inviting—and should help offset the fact that the rice was nearly burned to a cinder.
Right?! Now let's eat before it gets cold!
*munch* Oh my. This is...
DELICIOUS!
The hot dashi is spreading like liquid warmth throughout my frigid body...
Yeah. It's...strange.
Hm? How so?
I mean, we messed this rice up, right? It's both burned AND undercooked.
Yet we both find it delicious.
Correct on both counts.
Though I suppose the warmth of the dashi wouldn't be nearly as impactful were I not on the verge of freezing to death.
Mitsuba? What is it?
Oh, sorry. I was just remembering something my dad said.
Oh?
He said it a lot, actually: ＂The appeal of food isn't just something you experience with your taste buds.＂
＂Who are you eating with? Where are you eating it? And what did you do to get there?＂
It's about the environment surrounding the food—the experience that leads up to a meal. THAT'S what changes the appeal!
And it's why he focused on cultivating a certain atmosphere in the restaurant, and why we offered exceptional service.
Atmosphere and experience...
Interesting. Perhaps it is all the twists and turns of our recent journey that made this particular breakfast so tasty.
I think so—and I also think this is the first time I've experienced it for myself.
Truly?
I mean, I've always known it in theory, but as far back as I can remember, I've been caught up in the act of cooking.
I guess I never fully grasped the meaning behind what Dad said—especially after he passed away.
I spent all my time training so I could restore the restaurant, which made me lose sight of what it was supposed to BE.
Not exactly the cooking revelation I was looking for, but I think it's pretty important.
Well, I'm glad you were able to take something good from the experience.
Still, I remain surprised that restaurant cooking and outdoor cooking have so much in common.
Took me a long time to realize it, too. Guess I've still got growing to do, huh?
It'll be a long time before I can step into Dad's shoes for real...
Which is why I want to keep training right here in Alberia!
But I want to do it the RIGHT way— not with a bunch of constant worry and all-night cooking marathons.
I want to take my time, not rush. Really learn from the experience.
That's how I'm going to surpass him. I know it.
I look forward to that day—and as the manager of the Halidom's kitchen, I will continue to rely on you.
We're gonna make some AMAZING meals together, you and me!
Dear Mitsuba, Thank you for your letter. We're all happy to hear that you're doing well with your training.
But it's okay—you don't need to rush. It's true that running Nanakusa is a lot of work, but all of us here are dedicated to supporting it until the day you come back home.
PS: Come back home and visit sometime— and bring your friends from the Halidom! We'll welcome them with open arms and give them amazing service to thank them for all they've done for you.
